awd_titl_txt: Formation and Stability of Supported Metal Nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) program and the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM) program of the Division of Chemistry will support the collaborative research program of Prof. Patricia Thiel and Prof. James Evans of Iowa State University. Profs. Thiel and Evans and their students will study both the formation and stability of metal nanostructures supported on surfaces. They will consider both the effect of chemical additives of behavior, and also the additional complexity and functionality provided by multi-component systems. Detailed analysis and elucidation of these systems will be achieved by a closely integrated combination of experiment (scanning tunneling microscopy in combination with other surface analysis techniques) together with theory and simulation (from ab-initio DFT and semi-empirical analysis of energetics, to atomistic modeling using Kinetic Monte Carlo simulation and coarse-grained continuum modeling of the self-assembly and coarsening of epitaxial nanostructures). 

These studies will provide the basic scientific underpinnings for a range of nanotechnologies based on thin film deposition. The work will provide excellent educational training opportunities for graduate students and postdoctoral trainees in cutting-edge areas of nanoscale science and technology, nanostructure imaging and analysis, and predictive theory and multiscale modeling.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes for “Formation and Stability of Supported Metal Nanostructures” CHE-1111500

This project involved two key components. The first was to elucidate the kinetics and generally far-from-equilibrium structure of metal nanostructures (usually nanoclusters or NCs) formed by deposition on surfaces. For low-strain 2D epitaxial NCs on metal surfaces, we developed a strategy for atomic-level simulation of these processes with a precise ab-initio level description of both thermodynamics and kinetics (the latter being controlled by diffusion barriers for periphery diffusion, attachment-detachment, and intermixing in a vast number of local environments). The method was applied to elucidate unusual NC shape including chains and shape transitions in single component systems [Ni/NiAl(110), Au/Ag(100)], and also to reliably describe the formation of core-shell versus intermixed structures in bimetallic systems [(Ag+Au)/Ag(100), (Ni+Al)/NiAl(110)]. For 3D epitaxial NCs formed by deposition on graphite or formed by directed-assembly on rumpled graphene surfaces, we developed various appropriate atomistic models to capture the characteristics of ensembles of NC’s including sizes and spatial arrangement (rather than the detailed structure of individual NCs).

The second component of the project involved analysis of the stability of NCs formed as described above. We emphasize that in general nanoscale objects are only metastable due to their high perimeter length (for 2D NCs) or surface area (for 3D NCs). In particular we were interested the effect of additives (mainly sulfur) in destabilizing metal NCs due to the formation of metal-S complexes which might facilitate the transport of metal atoms (incorporated in the complex) across the surface. To this end we studies S adsorption on various metal surfaces, e.g., finding complex formation on Ag(111), Cu(111), but not on Au(111). We also studied the general effect of S in reconstructing metal surfaces for these and other surfaces. Other studies considered anomalous coarsening on anisotropic surfaces where rectangular NC’s shrink in length while retaining constant width (in contrast to the traditional coarsening mode which preserves equilibrated NC shape).

With regard to broader impact, this project is part of the professional platform which allows the PI and Co-PI to engage in sustenance of scientific societies or organizations. The Principal Investigator Thiel is a member of the Chemical Sciences Roundtable (CSR), an organization of the National Academy of Sciences that is charged with fostering understanding, education, and interaction among all segments of the chemical enterprise. She has organized CSR workshops on Chemistry Undergraduate Education and on Mesoscale Chemistry. Thiel is also an Associate Editor of the Journal of Chemical Physics, which is a premier (not-for-profit) journal of the American Institute of Physics. She was on the Editorial Board of Progress in Surface Science. The Co-PI, Evans, has been involved in organizing numerous scientific symposia for scientific professional organizations and networks at regional and national conferences on topics related to this NSF project. He also organized a summer school. Evans is also a member of the Editorial Board of the Journal of Chemical Physics (2013-2015), and of Computational Materials Science – Elsevier (2014-present), and Surface Science (2015-present). In all of these capacities, the PIs work to support the institutional scientific infrastructure.

In addition, the project provides the ideal training ground for the next generation of US scientists and academicians where they obtain the highest-level of training in a multidisciplinary field covering surface chemistry, thin film science, and nanoscale science. In addition they are exposed to the powerful strategy of integrated experimental and theoretical studies which will no doubt become increasingly common in advancing science. We have strong track record of launching junior scientists involved in our NSF projects (including this one) on highly successful careers.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/25/2016
Modified by: James W Evans
